title: Susan B. Anthony Papers: Daybook and Diaries, 1856-1906; Diaries; 1895

entries.fullText:
[Elizabeth][Eliz]Mary Lorne Dickenson
158 West 23rd Street
New York
Helen Potter
The Pelham
Boston - Mass -

10.75/00 24
Susan B. Anthony
Whoever finds this book
if in Rochester N.Y.
leave it 17. Madison Street
If in New York City - leave at
Mrs J.K. Laphaue's
no 10 - East 68th street
If in Philadelphia or N.J.
at 1238 Spring Garden Street
If in Chicago at the
[?] Walton Hotel
[?] of Chestnut & Clark Streets
But my home -
Rochester NY - will
always be the place!!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her travels and provides instructions on where to leave her book if found in different cities.

entries.fullText:
Measures of weight.- Avoirdupois: 1 pound equals
7000 grains; 16 drams, 1 ounce; 16 ounces, 1 pound; 112
pounds, 1 hundredweight; 20 hundredweight, 1 ton. Troy:
1 pound equals 5760 grains; 24 grains, 1 pennyweight; 20
pennyweights, 1 ounce; 12 ounces, 1 pound. Apothecaries’:
1 pound equals 5760 grains; 20 grains, 1 scruple; 3 scruples,
1 dram; 8 drams, 1 ounce; 12 ounces, 1 pound. Metric: 1
kilogramme equals 1000 grammes, equals 2.2 Avoirdupois
pounds.
Measures of length.- Customary: 12 inches equal 1
foot; 16 1/2 feet, 1 rod; 40 rods, 1 furlong; 8 furlongs, 1 statute
mile; 1 statute mile, 5280 feet or 1760 yards; 1 marine league,
3 nautical miles; 1 fathom, 6 feet; 1 nautical mile equals
6080.2 feet. Metric: 1000 millimetres equal 1 metre; 1000
metres, 1 kilometre; 1 metre equals 39.37 inches.
Surface or square measure.- Customary: 144
square inches equal 1 square foot; 9 square feet, 1 square
yard; 30.25 square yards, 1 square rod; 40 square rods, 1
square rood; 4 square roods, 1 acre; 640 acres, 1 square mile;
1 acre equals 208.7 feet square. Metric: 1 square metre equals
1 acre; 100 acres, 1 hectare; 1 hectare equals about 2.5 (2.47)
acres.
Solid or cubic measure.- Customary: 1728 cubic
inches equal 1 cubic foot; 27 cubic feet, 1 cubic yard; 40
cubic feet of round timber, 1 ton; 50 cubic feet of hewn timber, 1 ton; 128 cubic feet of wood (4 feet by 4 feet by 8 feet),
1 cord; 24.75 cubic feet of stone, 1 perch-usually 16 1/2 feet by
1 1/2 feet by 1 foot, but varies greatly. Metric: 1000 cubic
centimetres equal 1 litre, equals .946 quart.
Liquid measure.- English gallon equals 277.463 cubic
inches; U. S. gallon equals 231 cubic inches; 4 gills, 1 pint;
2 pints, 1 quart; 4 quarts, 1 gallon.
Dry measure.- 1 bushel equals 2150.42 cubic inches;
2 pints, 1 quart; 4 quarts, 1 gallon; 2 gallons, 1 peck; 4 pecks,
1 bushel. Metric: 10 millilitres equal 1 centilitre; 10 centilitres,
1 decilitre; 10 decilitres, 1 litre; 1 litre, 1.06 quarts.
Capacity of boxes
25 in. sq., 11.66 in. deep = Approx. 1 wine barrel.
20 “ “ 9.10 “ “ = “ 1 wine half barrel.
17 “ x 14 in. 9.00 “ “ = “ 1 bushel.
10 “ x 12 “ 9.00 “ “ = “ 1/2 “
8 “ in. sq., 8.40 “ “ = “ 1 peck.
8 “ “ 4.20 “ “ = “ 1 gal. (dry measure).
7 “ diam., 6.00 “ “ = “ 1 gal. (liquid measure).
entries.summaryText: This entry provides information on weights and measures, including measures of weight, length, surface or square measure, solid or cubic measure, liquid measure, dry measure, and capacity of boxes.

entries.fullText:
TO MEASURE APPLES, ETC., IN BIN.
To find the number of bushels of apples, potatoes, etc., in
a bin, multiply the length, breadth, and thickness together,
and this product by 8, and point off one figure in the product
for decimals.
entries.summaryText: This entry provides instructions on how to measure the number of bushels of apples, potatoes, etc. in a bin.

entries.fullText:
FIRST CLASS. - Letters and all written matter, whether
sealed or unsealed, and all other matter sealed, nailed, sewed,
tied, or fastened in any manner, so that it cannot be easily
examined, two cents per ounce or fraction thereof. A
"Special Delivery" ten-cent stamp when attached to a letter,
in addition to the lawful postage, shall entitle the letter
to immediate delivery at, or within one mile of, any post-office.
Postal cards, one cent each; with paid reply, two cents each.
SECOND CLASS. - All regular newspapers, magazines and
other periodicals issued at intervals not exceeding three
months; the postage is one cent for each four ounces,
payable by postage stamps.
THIRD CLASS. - Embraces printed books, pamphlets,
circulars, engravings, lithographs, proof-sheets and manuscript
accompanying the same, and all matter of the same general
character, and not having the character of personal correspondence.
Circulars produced by hektograph or similar process,
or by electric pen, are rated as third class. The limit of
weight for all matter of the third class is four pounds, except
in the case of single books exceeding that weight. The rate
of postage on mail matter of the third class is one cent for
each two ounces or fraction thereof.
FOURTH CLASS - All mailable matter not include in the
three preceding classes, which is so prepared fro mailing as
to be easily taken from the wrapper and examined. Rate,
one cent per ounce or fraction thereof, except seeds,
roots, cuttings, bulbs, plants and scions, which are 1 c. per two
ounces. Limit of weight,lbs. Full prepayment compulsory.
Liquids, and other like injurious matter, not admitted, except
under conditions which may be learned at any post-office.
Registry fee, eight cents, which, with the postage,
must be fully prepaid. The name and address of sender
must be given on the outside of envelope or wrapper.
POSTAL NOTE AND MONEY ORDER FEES. Postal notes,
3 c. each in denominations of $4.99 and less, payable to bearer,
such notes are invalid upon the expiration of three months
from the last day of the month of issue, but the holder can
after that time get it renewed at the Department at Washington,
upon payment of a fee of 3 cents. For Money Orders in
denominations of $100 or less, the following fees are charged:
Orders not exceeding $5, 5 c.; over $5 to $10, 8 c.; $10 to $15,
10 c.; $15 to $30, 15 c.; $30 to $40, 20 c.; $40 to $50, 25 c.; $50
to $60, 30 c.; $60 to $70, 35 c.; $70 to $80, 40 c.; $80 to #100, 45 c.
entries.summaryText: Explanation of domestic and foreign postage rates and fees.

entries.fullText:
TO CANADA (including Nova Scotia, New Brunswick,
Manitoba, and Prince Edward Island): LETTERS, two
cents for each ounce or fraction thereof; Books, Circulars,
and similar printed matter, one cent for each two
ounces or fraction thereof; SECOND CLASS MATTER,
same as in the United States; SAMPLES AND MERCHANDISE,
one cent per ounce. Packages must not exceed
4 lbs, 6 oz, in weight - prepayment compulsory.
entries.summaryText: Postage rates and fees for mailing to Canada.

entries.fullText:
On Algeria, Belgium, British India, Cape Colony, Constantinople,
Denmark, Dominion of Canada, Egypt, England,
France, German Empire, Hong Kong, Ireland, Italy, Jamaica,
Japan, Newfoundland, New South Wales, New Zealand,
Portugal, Sandwich Islands, Scotland, Shanghai,
Sweden, Switzerland, Tasmania, Victoria.

For Orders of $10 or less, 10c, | Over $50, not to exceed $60, 60c.
Over $10, not to exceed $20, 20c. | Over $60, not to exceed $70, 70c.
Over $20, not to exceed $30, 30c. | Over $70, not to exceed $80, 80c.
Over $30, not to exceed $40, 40c. | Over $80, not to exceed $90, 90c.
Over $40, not to exceed $50, 50c. | Over $90, not to exceed $100, $1.

Orders can also be obtained on Austria and East Indies by
remittance through the Postal Department of Switzerland,
subject to the rates of the Swiss Department to those countries.
Also on Norway and the Netherlands, through the
Postal Department of the German Empire, subject to the
rates of the German Department to those countries.
entries.summaryText: International or foreign money-order fees for various countries.

entries.fullText:
To all parts of the Universal Postal Union (embracing
nearly every civilized country):

ON LETTERS, five cents for each half ounce or fraction
thereof - prepayment optional. Double rates are collected
on delivery of unpaid or short-paid letters.
On newspapers, books, pamphlets, photographs, sheet
music, maps, engravings, and similar printed matter, one
cent for each two ounces or fraction thereof.
entries.summaryText: Postage rates for mailing to countries in the Universal Postal Union.

entries.fullText:
At Home
Had to dinner - May Hallowell &
Sarah Willis, Mr & Mrs W. C. Gannet &
friend, Miss Striker - Mr. & Mrs. Greenleaf &
Dr. & Mrs. Sanford, their Madeline -
- all went off [?] - with exactly
twelve at table
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a dinner party at home with a total of twelve guests including May Hallowell, Sarah Willis, Mr & Mrs W. C. Gannet, Miss Striker, Mr. & Mrs. Greenleaf, Dr. & Mrs. Sanford, and Madeline.

entries.fullText:
At home
But going over
to Ms Greenleafs ev'y
day from this on to
work with Mrs Mary
T. Sanford to straiten
out financial report
of last years State [?]
Con. campaign -
Isabel Howland
came last night -
and from this on
takes the matter in
hand -- I began it with
Mrs Sanford - this A.M.
of Dec. 26th and, we devoted
ourselves to [???ing] order
out of chaos --
entries.summaryText: Working with Mrs Mary T. Sanford to straighten out financial report of last year's State Con. campaign with Isabel Howland.

entries.fullText:
At home
but en route to
Mrs. Sanfords - went
to my dress makers
to find her too ill to
even see me - but
sent me word she
would fit me Saturday
A. M. so I went [?]
& she had furnished
me a beautiful [?]
with a satin star on
it.
entries.summaryText: Went to dress maker but she was too ill to see me. She will fit me on Saturday morning.

entries.fullText: Sister Mary, Isabel & self took tea at Mrs. Hallowells - met then Drs [Dolly?] & [Seary?] - Mrs Lucy B. Smith - Rev & Mrs Gannett - Mr Mathers of Natl Street & his young bride. We here learned that Perry Mark Parker is talking of forming an anti W.S. society in Rochester - & I said good - she will thereby only stir up every one who believes in equal rights to women - to publicly act & talk for it -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had tea with Sister Mary and Isabel at Mrs. Hallowell's where they met several people including Drs [Dolly?] and [Seary?], Mrs. Lucy B. Smith, Rev & Mrs Gannett, Mr Mathers and his young bride. They learned that Perry Mark Parker is talking of forming an anti W.S. society in Rochester.

entries.fullText: then to have dress fitted -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a dress fitting at home.

entries.fullText: Did not go to church. At 2 P.M. went to Board Meeting at State Industrial meeting - two men rebuked & fired for laying hands violently upon boys - There seems a determined secret - from me - to get the girls moved out of their building - & turn their building & everything over to the boys -, They know my earnest disapproval - so would not discuss the matter - though I asked it -
entries.summaryText: Attended a board meeting where two men were fired for laying hands on boys. There is a secret plan to move the girls out of their building and turn everything over to the boys.

entries.fullText: Went to Miss Fullams to have new waist to old black satin - & waist & skirt to another new dress fitted - Then home & worked over financial report with dear Rachel Howland - found several new items of receipts & outgrees to put in proper commities - my head has run on nothing else - than the loose - no way - in which the accounts were kept during the Campaign year
entries.summaryText: Went to get clothes fitted and worked on a financial report with Rachel Howland.

entries.fullText:
Left home on the 9.50
evg train for Cinci &
found Mrs Chapman
Catt on sleeper - so was
armed & equipped for
my southern trip -
Made final call on Mrs
Fulman - to try on new
dress - & then on Mrs
Greenleaf - to beg & implore
her not to contrive
to do treasuries work - but
to simply stick to the
President's duties -
On way to Station Sister
Mary with me - I called
on dear Maria Porter
88 - and Dr E. M. Moore
80 - the latter slowly recovering
from a partial paralysis -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left home for Cinci and met Mrs Chapman Catt on the train. She made some calls and visited Maria Porter and Dr E. M. Moore.

entries.fullText:
Breakfasted on
train & arrived in
Cincinnati at 10 -
Stopped at Burnett
House - dined &
took train for
Lexington at 4 P.M.
wrote letters home &
to sundry persons -
Arrived at Lexington
at 7 - Laura Clay met
us Depot - & took us to
her mother's home - a
dear old fashioned
house - heated; &
Soft coal grate fires
in each room - & a
hard coal stove fire
in the hall - but with
this cold snap - all was cold
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Cincinnati and took a train to Lexington where she was met by Laura Clay and stayed at her mother's home.

entries.fullText:
- Laura Clay and
No. 78 - North Broadway -
her mother - the noble woman
Mary June Warfield Clay
During the morning several
ladies called - though
the sleet & snow now falls,
the streets a glare of ice -
- a fair audience in the
old Christian Church -
now enclosed in centre
of their opposition nicely -
- Mrs C. P. Wyoming is a
very fine lecture - & just
fitted - complemented my
talk - a typical Southern
home is this of the Warfield
Clay - & she a fine, noble
woman - her daughter Mary
came up from Richmond
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at the old Christian Church in Lexington, Kentucky and compliments Mrs. C. P. Wyoming's lecture. She also visits Laura Clay and Mary June Warfield Clay at their home.

entries.fullText:
- Mrs Mary W. Hughes -
and Rev [?] Hughes - keep
a Methodist Boarding
School - & are of the primitive
"In the arms of Jesus" sort.
- everything [?ude] - each
girl making her own
grate fire - in her room -
no hall stove even to
take the chill off though
the water in tumbler &
wash bason froze hard
during the night in my room -
with a fire till 10 o'clock. -
A good, small audience
in their college chapel -
with 8 or 10 women from
the next town Nicholasville
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits a Methodist Boarding School in Wilmore, Kentucky run by Mrs. Mary W. Hughes and Rev [?] Hughes and speaks to a small audience in their college chapel.

entries.fullText: - Mrs Caroline A. Leech 1735 - First Street - Left Wilmore at 6.50 - the awfully cold air & ice in my room - found the car cold - a mean fire hardly started on the stove - at Lexington changed cars - but to find am equally cold one - arrive Louisville at 11. found Miss Leech at station - her mother too ill to entertain - so sent on to Mrs George Avery's - the son of my dear friend Susan took [?] - her youngest daughter - Helen Robinson came - Notwithstanding the mercury was 8 to 10 below zero 20 or more ladies called
entries.summaryText: Susan travels to Louisville, Kentucky to visit Caroline Leech and meets with Helen Robinson despite the cold weather.

entries.fullText: -- and at evg the Sunday school room !! of Unitarian Church was packed to suffocation - Mr. Jones - the pastor - introduced us - & we went stronger on talks with a sort of cross feeling that our cause should be degraded - by being put into such an inferior place - The friends ought to learn that to thus advertise for a little place - kills the meeting beforehand - Mrs Avery & Mrs Robnison went to Church Mrs C. & Self remained home to write & be quiet --
entries.summaryText: Susan attends a packed meeting at the Unitarian Church and expresses frustration with the venue choice.

entries.fullText:
Left Louisville at 8.20
reached O. at noon -
Several ladies met us
& took us to the Hotel -
Had a very good
audience in the U. S.
Circuit Court Room -
- But, oh dear - the
women are so W.C.T.U.
and so little woman
suffrage -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Louisville to Owensboro, KY and speaks to a good audience in the U.S. Circuit Court Room, but expresses disappointment with the women's W.C.T.U. and lack of support for woman suffrage.

entries.fullText:
Mrs James Roger
was our Hostess - our
meeting was in a
Campbellite Church
here - no Cumberland
Presbyterian Church -
On the A.M. of
the 16. Mrs Roger gave
us reception - with
luncheon - very
hospitable -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stays in Paducah, KY and attends a meeting at a Campbellite Church hosted by Mrs. James Roger. She also attends a reception with lunch the next day, hosted by Mrs. Roger.

entries.fullText: Guests of Mrs Husband a travelg 'man small audience - the Cumberland Presbyterian minister - Nelson - the only one who seemed to know a thing ahead Suffrage - a [?] little cold Opera house
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Milan Tennessee visiting Mrs. Husband and attended a small audience at the Cumberland Presbyterian church where the only person who seemed to know anything about suffrage was the minister named Nelson.

entries.fullText: The Women's Council Parlors were burned this very A. M. - so the meeting was in Young Men's Hebrew Associations Hall - A fine audience Mrs C. C. stopped with Mrs Selden - so I had a room to myself - Minor Meriwether of St Louis - was in our audience --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Memphis Tennessee and attended a meeting at the Young Men's Hebrew Associations Hall due to the Women's Council Parlors being burned down that morning. She had a room to herself as Mrs. C. C. stopped with Mrs. Selden. Minor Meriwether of St. Louis was also in attendance.

entries.fullText:
At 11- the 19th
Century Club gave
us a nice reception -
& we both made little
talks - in their
parlors -

Mr. Minnur
Merriweather to dinner
with us to-day -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a reception at the 19th Century Club in Memphis and has dinner with Mr. Minnur Merriweather.

entries.fullText:
at Ms. Merriweather's 14 Talbot St
at 9 A.M. went to Zions Hall
with Mrs. Cooper & Ms.
to a reception given by the
colored womens Club -

at 10:30 to the Y. Men's
Hebrew Associations Parlors -
to a reception given by the
Memphis Council comprised
of 45 local Women's
Associations - only the 19th
Century Club has not joined - &
it was Julia Ward Howe's influence
that kept it out -
This afternoon - we threw of [off?]
Miss Clara Conway's receptoin
given by her Alumni - at
her school - that we might
sleep & rest for the evening meeting
at the Young Men's Hebrew Hall
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends multiple receptions in Memphis, including one at the Y. Men's Hebrew Associations Parlors and one at the Young Men's Hebrew Hall.

entries.fullText:
Spoke in Colored Church
The Tabernacle at 11 - Mrs
C.C. also - a wonderful
assemblage - of all shades
from jet black to absolute
blonde white - most
pathetic - Mrs C. C.'s talk
to them was lovely -
"keep the soul on top" - we
dined at Mrs Meriwethers -
also Mrs Selden - & [?]
Unitarians - We left at
5.20 - I here presented
a set of History to Mrs M - &
one to the Secretary of the
Young Men's Hebrew Association
entries.summaryText: Spoke in Colored Church and dined with Mrs Meriwethers and Mrs Selden. Presented a set of History to Mrs M and one to the Secretary of the Young Men's Hebrew Association.

entries.fullText:
Reached New Orleans
at 8.20 - a Com. of
Portia Club - Mary
Stout Roddis, Kate
Nobles, the new Prest
Miss Huberwald &c
met us - were in
good time to find
Judge E. T. & Mrs C. E.
Merrick at breakfast -
- at six oclock dinner
they had all their family
J. B. Guthrie - son in law
son Ned & wife - loveliest
of Southern girl - then
[?] their grand daughters
one great niece or one Grand
son - & all, enjoyed
the time highly --
entries.summaryText: Met with the Portia Club in New Orleans and had dinner with Judge E. T. & Mrs C. E. Merrick and their family.

entries.fullText:
New Orleans - La -
Caroline E. Merrick
1404 - Napoleon Avenue -
Spent forenoon tromping
through the old French
quarters - Market &c -
Too dirty for any use -
Both Mrs C. C. & self took
a napp in P.M - Had a
packed audience in Assembly
room of the High School
- Mrs Merrick introduced me,
before Mrs C. C. - Mr J.
Birney Guthrie [?] - just
taken off his feet with
the charming C. C. - she
never spoke better —

Mrs C. C. left at 8 & spoke at Mc
[?] to night.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits New Orleans, Louisiana and spends the day with Caroline E. Merrick, visiting the French quarters and Market. They both take a nap in the afternoon and attend a packed audience in the Assembly room of the High School where Mrs. Merrick introduces Susan B. Anthony before Mrs. C.C. Mrs. C.C. leaves at 8 and speaks at Mc[?] to night.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Merrick called with me
on her son Ned's wife &
their babies & the youngest
Susan B. - after Mrs M's
step mother - & self - Then
on Mary Stout Raddis -
her daughter, not in - they
own a neat little place
at 1526 - Henry Clay Street -
- Kate Nobles & others called
Mrs Ordway - brought her $50 -
the Grandson - J. Birney Guthrie
& Mrs O. accompanied me to
Jackson St Ferry - & [?]
Bing crossed over the
Miss. with me - & waited
until 6.40 - till the train
came -- about midnight
we came to a freight train
wreck - & had to get-up, dress
& walk past it - & take
the East bound train - & again
West - to bed & slept until
10 morning -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day with Caroline E. Merrick, visiting her son's wife and their babies, and Mary Stout Raddis. They also receive visits from Kate Nobles and Mrs. Ordway who brought $50. J. Birney Guthrie and Mrs. O. accompany Susan B. Anthony to Jackson St Ferry. They encounter a freight train wreck and have to walk past it to take the East bound train.

entries.fullText:
Mrs C. C. at Greenvile - this night
Wea. THUR. JAN. 24, 1895 Ther.
Shreveport, La.
Mrs M. F. Smith
847 - Jordan St -
notify Prof C. E. B[Boyd]yrd
Byrd - Head of [C?]
High School - he & bride
board with Mrs Smith -
Mrs S. A. widow for eight
years - with five sons -
a bright woman - in great
lovely house - built new
just before her husbands death
- Did not arrive until
2 P.M. on account of
freight smash up - half
way from New Orleans -
Was one of Star Lecture
course - had Court House
packed with best people - the
Hypatia Club - sent me
two beautiful bouquets - but
every one is deploring the
loss of flowers by the cold of
entries.summaryText: Mrs C. C. at Greenvile - this night. Mrs M. F. Smith, Prof C. E. Boyd, Mrs S. A. and the Hypatia Club were mentioned. The entry talks about a lecture course and a freight smash up.

entries.fullText:
Left S. at 8.15 -
Master Leon Smith
going station with me -
Mrs Blanks of Monroe
on train & talked all the way -
on arriving at the
Miss. River - we waited two
hours & more for Ferry
Boat - so train was too
late for me to speak
at Jackson - Mrs C. C. [?]
& Miss Powers came to
the train at 9.20 - & said
Mrs. C. C. was holding a
magnificent audience for
my coming - but, I had
bought my ticket & rechecked
baggage to Birmingham
- & was to dozed
out to even be looked at -
much less to try to speak
in Miss. Hall of Representatives
packed with southern
Chivalry —
entries.summaryText: The entry talks about a train journey with Mrs Blanks of Monroe and Master Leon Smith. Mrs C. C. and Miss Powers were mentioned. The train was too late for the author to speak at Jackson. The author was too dozed out to even be looked at much less to try to speak in Miss. Hall of Representatives packed with southern Chivalry.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Mary Bolls van Hook
2022 - F. Avenue
arrived at 5. A.M - found
Mrs. Van H. moved &
so went to Hotel Morris - to
await events - see
roster up - Miss Susan
Jolly called - said her
sister had gone to Montgomery
to get bill through Legislation - &
that her mother Mrs.
Richardson Jolly wished me to
stop with her so I left my
comfortable steam heated room
with misgivings & found a bare
southern house cold - & other
little coal grates couldn't touch
the cold - so [?] - was the
condition - Mrs. P.B didn't arrive -
to send trunk back to the hotel &
went back to my room
after my lecture
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Birmingham, Alabama and stays with Mrs. Richardson Jolly after being unable to stay in her steam heated room. She mentions that Miss Susan Jolly's sister had gone to Montgomery to get a bill through Legislation.

entries.fullText:
Left B. at 11.50 -
for Decatur - (new)
guest of Harvey Lewis
who - with Mrs. C.C.C. met
me at new D. Station -
Mrs. C.C. had arrived on
January - Here we had
a nice warm room -
- - All day the oldest
inhabitant never
saw such a
cold - freezing time!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Birmingham and goes to Decatur where she is a guest of Harvey Lewis and Mrs. C.C.C. She mentions the extreme cold weather.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. E.S. Hildreth-to be
entertained by Mrs. Harvey Lewis.
The Lewis' are northern
people as are most
of the residents of
New Decatur- Had
a fair audience in
the Opera House in
Old Decatur-though
the rain & slush
& snow kept most
people at home-
entries.summaryText: Mrs. E.S. Hildreth was entertained by Mrs. Harvey Lewis in New Decatur, Alabama. They had a fair audience in the Opera House despite the bad weather.

entries.fullText:
The home of our dear old
national's long time ago
Vice Pres for Alabama-
Mrs. Priscilla Holmes Drake
the mother of Mrs. Buel
McClung of Knoxville & Mrs. M. O.
Brooks of Washington -and
Mrs. Robinson of near
Huntsville ,who was at
our meeting
We arrived at 6. P.M. had
City Hall packed -guests
of Mrs. Milton Hume- daughter
of an Ex. Gen. Chapman- &
sister of Mrs. Taylor of
Denver Col- The Pres. of
the local club-Mrs. C. C. Clay
& now Mrs Klopton- was
at Mrs. Hume's - a splendid
typical southern lady- the Humes
is a magnificent old slave
holders mansion -but
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Huntsville, Alabama and met with Mrs. Priscilla Holmes Drake, Mrs. Buel McClung, Mrs. M. O. Brooks, and Mrs. Robinson. They had a packed City Hall and were guests of Mrs. Milton Hume, daughter of an Ex. Gen. Chapman and sister of Mrs. Taylor of Denver Col. Mrs. C. C. Clay, the President of the local club, was also present.

entries.fullText:
getting there after dark
& leaving it at 3.20 A.M.
before daylight- Saw
only the rooms inside-
At Knoxville we found
our board the Clay's &
other Kentucky delegates
& Miss Hay -also,
Mrs. Ketchum of Michigan
Reached the Aragon
about noon-found
Rev Anna, Lucy E. & Mrs
Upton with H. Augusta,
Claudia & Miriam
Howard there - with
everything in order for us
- lovely room with light
fire-Hotel very nice &
warm - held Ex. Con. meeting
in ev'g 22 states represented
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived at Knoxville and met with delegates from Kentucky and Michigan before reaching Aragon where they held an Ex. Con. meeting with 22 states represented.

entries.fullText:
27th National A.W.S.A. Con. to
be in Atlanta, Georgia
For the first time moved
out of Washington D.C. since
1869-when dear Lucretia
Mott was president
Opened with a
splendid audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended the 27th National A.W.S.A. Con. which was moved out of Washington D.C. for the first time since 1869 and opened with a splendid audience.

entries.fullText:
27th National Con -
Atlanta - Geo - DeGives
Opera House
entries.summaryText: Summary not provided

entries.fullText:
27th Annual National Con -
DeGives Opera House
Atlanta - Georgia
entries.summaryText: Summary not provided

entries.fullText:
- ought to be Wash. Con. DeGive's Opera House
Atlanta Georgia
Rev Anna H. Shaw preached -
The Heavenly Vison" at 3 P.M.
in the Opera House - packed
to suffocation, - the stage
& all standing room - &
hundreds turned away
by the Police -
Dr Hathorne had
preached against us
in the morning - Baptist -
which stirred Anna
to greater power -
In the evening our women
spoke in various white
& colored churches - but
I sat in Parlors & held
Council with all who
came in -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a sermon by Rev Anna H. Shaw at Wash. Con. DeGive's Opera House in Atlanta Georgia. Dr Hathorne had preached against them in the morning. In the evening, women spoke in various white and colored churches while Susan held council with all who came in.

entries.fullText:
27th Annual National Con -
Atlanta - Georgia
Went to the Atlanta
University at 9 A.M. and
talked to the colored students
at 10 - went into Executive
Com. meeting in Hotel
Aragon - until 2 P.M. -
- and in afternoon
[High School Assembly] again until dark -
- then dressed in velvet
& was whirled to colored
Bethel Church - met
Bishop Turner there - &
Mrs Merrick & I talked
to a 1000 or more - some
whiter than me - still
doomed to go with the
blakest - then returned
to the Aragon Reception -
& shook hands with the
hundreds that surged through
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended the 27th Annual National Con in Atlanta, Georgia. She talked to colored students at Atlanta University and went into an Executive Com. meeting in Hotel Aragon. In the afternoon, she attended a High School Assembly and later went to Bethel Church where she met Bishop Turner and Mrs Merrick and talked to a 1000 or more. She then returned to the Aragon Reception and shook hands with the hundreds that surged through.

entries.fullText:
Talking & saying goodbye
to everybody -
At 3:30 - Sister Mary
& self were taken
to the High School
assembly room - to
meet the High School
Alumnae - Only 100 -
out of their 600 -
members were present
Their president is -
Mr. Cox —
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Atlanta saying goodbye to everyone and meets with the High School Alumnae.

entries.fullText:
Left Atlanta - GA - at
7:30 - for Columbus - GA
where we arrived at 11:30.
H. Augusta Howard - our
escort - the mother Mrs.
Ann Jane Linsey Howard,
Claudia H. Maxwell,
Miriam H. Dubose & her
litle boy Howard DuBose - had
gone home before us - only
company consisted of Sister
Mary S. Anthony - Rev Anna
Shaw & niece Lucy E. Anthony,
Harriet Taylor Upton and her little
friend Bessie Gilbert of Ohio -
- We found the Howard
home - a veritable old
slave-holders Mansion -
75 or 80 feet front - with twin
great columns - and at
the sides five great columns
making a piazza on three sides -The
hall is 20 feet wide - each of the
four great square rooms on its sides
are fully 25 feet - with one fire place
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Atlanta and arrives in Columbus, GA where she visits the Howard home.

entries.fullText:
At Columbus -
I've parlor & dining room
have soft coal grates -
All the other great
room up stair & down
have old fashion fireplaces
with hand irons -
but not the great old
back logs or fore-sticks -
instead - The wood
was small - &r its burning piles
hardly touched the
frigid air of the rooms -
- As we 8 & 10 hovered round
the parlor fire - our frozen
breaths formed as if out
side - But the hearts
of the Howard's are great,
gave us a cordial
welcome —
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Columbus and describes the fireplaces in the house she is staying at.

entries.fullText:
At Columbus -
Rev. Anna H. Shaw - Harriet
Taylor Upton - Sister Mary, Niece
Lucy E. & Bessie Gilbert - left
for Atlanta, these for different
places at 3.20 - which
left S.B.A. the only
visitor - Over this dear
consciencious family
hangs a heavy cloud -
A sadness reigns over
the house - The other two
daughters at home are
Ruth & Alice - There
there are three other girls
married - and two sons -
all opposed to W. Rights -
& all the reforms that
the mother & five home girls
have espoused - They have
Old Tom. & old - 80 years old
who were Mr. H's father's
Linsby's slaves —
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is the only visitor left in the house she is staying at in Columbus. The family she is staying with is sad because they are opposed to women's rights and reforms that the mother and five home girls have espoused. There are also two former slaves in the house.

entries.fullText:
S.B.A. Left - Columbus
at 2.45 - In Aiken S.C
Dear Claudia H. Maxwell -&
Mirians H. Du Bose's son, Howard
took me to the station -
Found one train two
Columbus Ga - Men -
Col. C J. Thornton - a lawyer-
and L. F. Humbel -
a real estate and loan agent -
- who talked & told me
of many things of the
old life - & of the new -
- and of dear Ruth -
reached Marion at 8.20, - &
there took the most ancient
sleeper I ever saw - to
Augusta - There at 6:20. took
Train for Aiken —
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Columbus to Aiken, stopping in various locations and meeting different people along the way.

entries.fullText:
Arrived at Aiken S.C.
at 7.15 - found all in bed -
But Miss. Schofield soon had
her fires going - she had taken
home with her from Atlanta
- Emily Howland, Mrs Hubbard,
Mr and Mrs Tilney of Phila - Dr Jane
Myers & Mrs Blankenburg - Phebe
Wright, the Canada Friend, &
Miss MComas of Brooklyn - &
my arrival made nine -
The weather cold but
bright & lovely - we visited
the Old peoples House -
some [?] - all 70 or over -
Old Pompey told of his
Slavery life - no Patrick
Henry could have writhered
under bondage more battered
than did Pompey - George
Washington - another character -
- talk about the loneliness of
the patriarchal family!! every slave
with a spark of the love of
liberty in his soul repelled
against it —
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Aiken and spends time with Miss. Schofield and other guests. They visit the Old peoples House and hear stories of slavery from Old Pompey.

entries.fullText:
Martha Schofield- she
has kept a Boarding and
Industrial School for
colored youth here for
30 years - This morning
light found the ground
white & the trees weighted
down with snow and
the cold & snow together -
kept her 100 day scholars at
home - save 8 or 10 - So
I could see & talk only
to the boarding scholars -
She took me to the shops
carpenter, Harness, Blacksmith
&c - Had small but best
representative audience - The
Baptist minister presented me -
- all of went in an Omnibus
the Court House was very cold
two it had two stoves & one
grate fire going at red heat —
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Martha Schofield's Boarding and Industrial School for colored youth in Aiken, S.C. during a snowstorm and gives a speech to a small audience.

geographicalLocations: Cor. Gordon St and Richland Avenue
entries.fullText:
Mrs. Helen Brayton
member Board of Lady Managers of
Columbian expedition -
Arsenal Hill - Cor. Gordon St
and Richland Avenue -
Found Col. V. P. Clayton -
chair Practical Progress Com.
that invited me to speak in C.
and Col. Brayton at the
station at 11.30 - left Aiken
at 7.15 - Found Mrs
Brayton a lovely northern
woman - with two young
daughters - Mr B. a northern
also - they have lived here 20
years - & gone through all the
tribulations of the Klu Klux days
Had some 100 - in the
Opera House - the cold of
it something fearful - only
one little stove in the far corner
by the door - not the breath
of fire on the stage!! Col
Clayton introduced me —
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at the Opera House in Columbia, South Carolina, after being invited by Col. V. P. Clayton and Mrs. Helen Brayton, a member of the Board of Lady Managers of the Columbian expedition.

entries.fullText:
At Col. Brayton
a constant run of
callers - the real old
Southern blood - At
4.15 - Mrs B. & self went
Mrs Smith's - of Wilkesbarre
Pa - to a small reception -
- The Smith's spend winters
in Columbia - in a
real comfortable furnace
heated palatial house -
& summers in Penn -
Mrs. Le Conte - the State
Librarian - though the Con.
of S.C. says none but electors
shall hold office - Gov Tillman
and the legislation
over rode the law & elected
"woman - twice over - against
many men aspirants" -
Met two daughter of Gilman
Perkins of Rochester at Smith's
Took train at 6 P.M - two hours late -
I was in bed before it started
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a reception at Mrs. Smith's in Wilkesbarre, Pennsylvania and meets Mrs. Le Conte, the State Librarian. She also mentions Governor Tillman and the legislation that allowed women to hold office. She then takes a train to an unknown location.

entries.fullText:
Culpepper - Va.
Mrs Orra Langhorne
Arrived 8. A.M. two hours
late - Train flagged to stop -
so conductor hustled me off.
Trunk also - & saved me
from the two hours into - & out
again - from Washington - Found
no room with fire at the
Waverly - So man escorted
me to Mrs. Rixey's boarding house -
where Mrs. Langhorne had
engaged room for me -
cheerless and barren enough - but
a hard coal fire in old
fashion Franklin stove -
Weather very cold and bright sun -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Culpepper, Virginia and stays at Mrs. Rixey's boarding house after her train is two hours late. She notes the weather is very cold and sunny.

entries.fullText:
This day rounds out
my 75th year - & starts
me into my 76th - I am
now but about ten years younger
than our dear mother
when she passed to the
beyond - & 6 years older than
our dear Father when he went.
Banquet at Ebbitt House.
200 sat at table -
Rachel announced that she
had obtained $5,000 &
placed in The Penn Mutual
Life Insurance Company - &
that it would hence forth
pay S.B.A. an annuity of
$800 = It was a great
surprise to S.B.A.
probably every other one knew
of it - but her --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony celebrates her 75th birthday and receives a surprise annuity of $800.

entries.fullText:
First Annual Business
meeting at the Ebbitt House
Washington D.C --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the First Annual Business meeting at the Ebbitt House in Washington D.C.

entries.fullText: Wea. TUES. FEB. 19, 1895 Ther.

Women's Council -
business session of only the
members & delegates &
Frederick Douglas entered
the hall - Mrs Sewell, at
once, called him to the
platform - and when he
hesitated, she appointed
Meritt Anthony & Rev. Anna Shaw
to escort him to the platform -
he went - bowed most graciously
& gracefully - but declined to say
a word - then sat there through the
session - & again returned at the
P.M session - & sat till near its
close - I chatted with him a half-hour -
on returning to his home in
Anacostia - he dropped dead
as he was telling his wife of that
wonderful Women's meeting -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Frederick Douglas attending the Women's Council business session and his subsequent death after returning home.

entries.fullText: Wea. Sat. Feb 23, 1895 Ther.

In Washington.
Rev Ida C. Huttun
preached the C[?]
sermon at 8pm
Mrs. Sewall and self
called on Mrs.
Douglas and her
children.
entries.summaryText: Attended a sermon by Rev Ida C. Huttun and visited Mrs. Douglas and her children in Washington.

entries.fullText: The funeral of Frederick Douglass at 2, P.M. in the colored M.E. Metropolitan Church -
entries.summaryText: Attended the funeral of Frederick Douglass in Washington.

entries.fullText: In Washington
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a short entry on February 27, 1895, stating that she was in Washington.

entries.fullText: In Washington - at court - from 5. to 7 - A beautiful reception given by Mrs. J. R. McLean - to S. B. A -
entries.summaryText: On February 28, 1895, Susan B. Anthony attended a beautiful reception given by Mrs. J. R. McLean in Washington, where she spent time at court from 5 to 7.

entries.fullText:
National W. S. A. even'g of the
Women's Council. My title will be
Women's Work & the Ballot.
After me came Mrs. Grammer
also I D was happy about
Mrs. Chapman Catt. A splendid
guartable of my girls -
a splendid audience.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at the National W. S. A. evening of the Women's Council about Women's Work & the Ballot. She mentions Mrs. Grammer and Mrs. Chapman Catt and is happy about the latter. She also notes a splendid audience and guartable of her girls.

entries.fullText:
Closing meeting of
the Women's Council
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the closing meeting of the Women's Council.

entries.fullText:
In Washington
for National Suffrage
Woman's Com. meeting
all the day - in evening
a meeting of friends
in our parlor
entries.summaryText: Attended National Suffrage Woman's Committee meeting in Washington all day and had a meeting with friends in the evening.

entries.fullText:
In Washington
in [?]
Ex. Com. meeting
all day - & at 6
Rachel, May and self
with Mrs. Rapley
[?]
entries.summaryText: Attended Executive Committee meeting in Washington all day and met with Rachel, May, and Mrs. Rapley at 6 PM.

entries.fullText:
Mr & Mrs E. J. Ramson
Friends - she the wife
of son of Samuel M.
Jarmes the preacher
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her friends Mr & Mrs E. J. Ramson and their connection to Samuel M. Jarmes, a preacher.
No entry written on this day.

entries.fullText:
Left Washington D.C.
10. A.M. with Emily Howland
reached Philadelphia at 1-
Lunched in Penn. station -
- Miss H. went to Mrs Ellen
Childs 624 Race st - & I went
to the house of dear
Adeline Thomson - who
died Feb. 2 - & was buried
Feb. 4. While Sister Mary, Niece
Lucy E. - Anna Shaw, Rachel Foster
and self were all at the
Atlanta Con - & her
nephew - so says Nellie
Parish - forbade our being
notified of her death
Only Bell & son Theodore were in
the house 1236 Spring Garden - &
all looked cold & deserted
Edgar had stripped things quickly
Then took train at 4.50 for
Somerton - where were Rev Anna
Lucy E, Anna O. and Mrs Robbins of
Mich, the new Con. Sec. of Council -
- the girls returned to [?] at
[?] - & Miller arrived same train -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Washington D.C. to Philadelphia and visits Adeline Thomson's house. She attends the Atlanta Con and learns of Thomson's death, which her nephew forbade them from being notified of. She then travels to Somerton.

entries.fullText:
In Somerton. At R. J. A.' s -
signed my name over 200
times on sheets - to thank
the friends who sent Rachel
money to make up the sum
that is to bring me $800 - a
year - So long as I live -
At 4.50 I returned to
Phila - to 1820 Diamond Street -
Took supper & slept [thr?] -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony signs her name over 200 times to thank friends who sent Rachel money. She then returns to Philadelphia and sleeps at 1820 Diamond Street.

entries.fullText: Wea Wed March 13, 1895

Left cousin S. V. Laphams at 8.20 - Miss [Norse?] went to Jersey station - Hoboken- West Shore R.R.. - Left at 9.20 and reached Rochester at 9.12 - evening - Found Sister Mary up - alone - girl Sarah - out -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from cousin S. V. Laphams to Rochester and finds Sister Mary alone with girl Sarah out.

entries.fullText:
At home. Rochester
Sister May read of two state
Industrial school girls & Two Ind
Academy boys - girls arrested - So am
sent to Police Court. Found case
adjourned to Monday A.M.
Paper announced the death
of our dear and noble friend
Elizabeth P. Hall of 47
Frank St. - last night near 12 oclock-
We went there. Found
many already before us. Rev.
Dennis her nearest friend was
there. Helping the dear girl
Allie Mornam
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home in Rochester and learns about the arrest of four students. She also attends the funeral of her friend Elizabeth P. Hall.

entries.fullText:
At home.
The files of letters &
papers accumulated
during my over two months
absence are simply
appalling.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home and is overwhelmed by the amount of letters and papers that have accumulated during her two-month absence.

entries.fullText:
At home -
Sister Mary & self went
to church - Then home
to an old fashion - apple
pot pie dinner - Which
brought of the living - brothers
Daniel & Merritt - & Aaron
& of those gone - Father especially
but mother also - for she did
so love to make what pleased
father so well & ever & always did so
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at home with her sister Mary, attends church, and has a family dinner.

entries.fullText:
Rochester - In A.M. Sister
Mary & self went to Police Court
to see the two bad girls tried by
Judge Ernest - They sentenced
to prisons - Son of Hope - &
[Albion?] - Their boy accomplices
not arrested even -
Simply used as witnesses
against the girls --
Then back to dinner
and at 2.20 - to the
funeral of Elizabeth P. Hall.
76 years old - Rev
Dennis read the Episcopal
service - without a single
extemporaneous word of the
wonderful spirit that had
left its earthly tabernacle -- and
with a pathos in his voice
showing the depth of his feeling
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the trial of two girls in police court and the funeral of Elizabeth P. Hall in Rochester.

entries.fullText:
-
Sister Mary & Mrs Crossalt
of Warsaw went to Watson
House - P.E. Clerk Sociable
and I to state school
annual meeting -
but no quorum came - so
a little after 9 I was
home & in bed -
entries.summaryText: Attended state school annual meeting but no quorum came.

entries.fullText:
-
Mrs Hunts - Belle Bristol
of Nampa - Idaho - called
& talked over amendment
matters in her state -
- clearly our National
house had better be kept
off - & let their own
politicians manage it -
they have precipitated it -
entries.summaryText: Discussed amendment matters in Idaho with Belle Bristol.

entries.fullText:
At Home
In evening Sister Mary
& self went over &
called on Miss Wells
& Mrs Gannetts --
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary and Susan B. Anthony visited Miss Wells and Mrs. Gannetts at home.

entries.fullText:
At home -
Got off 20 letters or
more - & in P.M.
went to Dr. Farleys - to
listen reading of Sally
Hally's letters - extracts
& Carrie Putnam - which
carried us back to the
olden times -- - Took
Miss Wells to Young Peoples
Party - but found no supper -
- So came home to cold
water & bread & butter --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony listened to the reading of Sally Hally's letters and Carrie Putnam's extracts at Dr. Farleys. She also went to a Young Peoples Party with Miss Wells but found no supper and came home to cold water and bread and butter.

entries.fullText: at home - with type writer - paid off Julia Ames - She hasn't the education nor the quick perception to ever make a success of type writing & stenography
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home and pays off Julia Ames. She comments on Ames' lack of education and perception for success in type writing and stenography.

entries.fullText: Sunday A.M. Sister Mary went to hear Mr Gannett - Miss Wells to colored church - & at 1. we all went to Dr & Mrs Sanfords to dinner - then to 2d Baptist Church - Dr Anderson introduced Mrs Wells to a good audience - & she began "My country tis of thee"- which [?] had sung - & clearly proved it wasn't her cont.. - oh lord it rained - Sister Mary went with her to Rev [Thearts?] to tea - & Niece to 1st Baptist Church- & there was a still larger audience - at close of her speech a Texas theological student brutally asked questions which answered beautifully - o at last to throw in my word - that proscription of color was rampant here in Rochester &c
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends church and dinner with family and friends. She comments on a speech given by Mrs. Wells and a theological student's questions. She also mentions the rampant proscription of color in Rochester.

entries.fullText:
Ida B. Wells of Memphis - guest
Went to see Mrs Fullam about dresses
for California trip - sold typewriter
Anna Dorsey - to ask Miss Wells if she
would like to dictate her letters & have them
written on the typewriter - When I
returned. I found Miss Wells scribbling
away- & said couldn't you dictate ,
let Anny type write for you." - oh yes -
if I had had a chance"- then I went
to my room & said - "you didn't understand
me did you to ask Mrs W. " - yes, she
said - but I didn't choose to write for a
colored woman" - I engaged to work for you?
- Well - When I ask an employee to do a
favor to a guest I expect her to comply -
- so the little fatherless & homeless girl
of 20 - left - - The Presbyterian ministers this
A.M. passeded a resolution against Lynching -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Ida B. Wells visiting and her experience with a typewriter and a former employee's refusal to help Wells.

entries.fullText:
at home -
Miss Wells here to supper
- Democrat Reporter
called - gave him the
story of Miss Wells & Mr
Clark at Burke's store
- start of my type writer
&c - but the Dem. Chron
never published it -
nor did it allude
to the outrage editorially -
at 9 Oclock Miss Wells
left - & went to her
colored friend's Mrs Morse -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about having Miss Wells over for supper and a Democrat Reporter visiting. She also mentions Miss Wells leaving to visit a friend.

entries.fullText:
take the 10.15 - A.M. Rome,
Watertown -- Guest at Mrs.
Charles Gaylord - Meeting
in opera house - Fair
audience - roads too muddy
for farmers to come in -
entries.summaryText: Attended a meeting in Sodus with a fair audience, roads were too muddy for farmers to come in.

entries.fullText:
Reached Rochester from
Sodus at 11.20 - Found
all right - -
entries.summaryText: Arrived in Rochester from Sodus.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: At home

entries.fullText: At home —
entries.summaryText: At home —

entries.fullText:
Sunday - didn’t go
to church - Sister May
went - Both of
us dined & Mary H.
Hallowells - Sarah Willis,
Phebe Hallowell, Lucy B,
Smith - Mr. & May Piatt -
& Wm Stout & little wife -
had a nice old fashion
visit & remained till dark
A special Board
meeting of State Industrial
school, at 4 - but I didn’t
go - just feel that it
is no use holding the
place any longer - hoping
some woman will come
to the front to take it -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends Sunday with family and friends, and mentions a special Board meeting of State Industrial school.

entries.fullText:
At home
Went to Mrs Fullams
to try on dresses—
wrote letter to
Gov. Levi P. Morton -
resigning my place as
member of Board of
managers state Industrial
School - & recommended
Dr George W. Goler - as the
one best suited - -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes a letter to Gov. Levi P. Morton resigning her place as member of Board of managers state Industrial School and recommends Dr George W. Goler as the one best suited.

entries.fullText:
Received the Governor’s
acceptance of my
resignation -

Sister Mary & self
went Watson House
to hear Mrs H B. Clark’s
paper on “Ethics in the
Public Schools” - it was
excellent is to be read at
the Women’s Ethical Club
on Friday P.M at the 2d
Baptist Church
entries.summaryText: Received the Governor’s acceptance of my resignation and attended a paper reading on Ethics in the Public Schools with Sister Mary.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary & self
went Watson House
to hear Mrs H B. Clark’s
paper on “Ethics in the
Public Schools” - it was
excellent is to be read at
the Women’s Ethical Club
on Friday P.M at the 2d
Baptist Church
entries.summaryText: Attended a paper reading on Ethics in the Public Schools with Sister Mary at Watson House by Mrs H B. Clark, which is to be read again at the Women’s Ethical Club on Friday P.M at the 2d Baptist Church.

entries.fullText:
[Franklinvelle Galt. Co. N.J.
guest of]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was a guest in Franklinvelle Galt. Co. N.J.

entries.fullText:
Franklinville - Catt. Co NY.
Mrs. Lucy F.T. Waring - President
P.E. Club. - organize week before
Lecture in Opera House -
Guest of Mr & Mrs Sexton -
Mrs Groves is secretary -
Mrs Jennie E. Dudley Mason
called - her father was John
Dudley, who used to fold, press
& bale the cloth - in my fathers
Cotton Factory at [Bakersville?] [?]
Mr Dudley had twin sons -
Nelson tended the surging machine
& Alanson was -later superintendent
of weaving room-
Brother D. R. took to Adams
- they dined at her uncle
Crawford’s - & then went
to Aunt Hannah Moxie's
who must have lived in house
he was born in - [Bornen’s Corner?]
Mrs Dudley Masons mothers
name was Hodskin - New
Ashford - Cheshire - Mass —
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a lecture in Opera House in Franklinville, Catt. Co NY. She was a guest of Mr & Mrs Sexton. She also met with Mrs Jennie E. Dudley Mason and learned about her family's history in the cotton factory business.

entries.fullText:
at home
getting ready
to start for
California
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home getting ready to start for California.

entries.fullText:
Left Rochester - 7.20 A.M.
via Solomon reached
Warren Ohio - Mrs Harriet
Taylor Uptons - at 4. P.M.-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Rochester and reached Warren Ohio, where she met with Mrs Harriet Taylor Uptons.

entries.fullText:
Left Warren at 4
p.m. Took sleeper at
Cleveland for Indianapolis.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Warren and took a sleeper at Cleveland for Indianapolis.

entries.fullText:
Arrived Indianapolis
at 7.20 a.m. in time
to breakfast with dear
May Wright Sewall Whose
heart is wrung because
of the illness & absence in
Arizona of her dear husband
Theodore S. Sewall. We
talked over council &
California between her
almost constant engagements.
but her one
thought was on her
Theodore & his being far away
from her. She wrote about
his cure almost hopless & it
is well she can keep up
hope.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Indianapolis and had breakfast with May Wright Sewall, who was worried about her husband's illness and absence in Arizona. They talked about council and California, but May's thoughts were on her husband Theodore. May wrote about his almost hopeless cure and her hope for his recovery.

entries.fullText:
Took the 11.00 a.m. train
for Chicago - Arrived at
5.00 - Found dear Mrs.
Gross watching and waiting on
me - Called at Studio
& took Harriet Hasmer
to 48 Lake Shore Drive - She
has been a guest with the
Gross' for seven months -
- She is at work on
Statue of Lincoln -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Chicago and visits Mrs. Gross and Harriet Hasmer.

entries.fullText:
[St. Louis - Mo
Mrs. E. B. Ingalls
4119 Westminster Place]
- Went to Woman's Club
in P.M. - They were talking
of Celia Maxter - Called
on me - &
At - 9.20 P.M.
Mrs. Gross & self took
Alton train for St. Louis -
Mr. Gross accompanying us
to the station --
Miss Shaw came
to Mrs. Gross at 2 P.M. --
so went with us to St. Louis
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits the Woman's Club in St. Louis and meets with Mrs. E. B. Ingalls, Celia Maxter, Mrs. Gross, and Miss Shaw.

entries.fullText:
This day is for St. Louis
Mrs. E. B. Ingalls.
4119 - Westminster Place.
Mrs Gross & self arrived
St. Louis & with Miss Shaw
went to the new Planter's
Hotel - Opposite the old County
Court House - in where
Negro - Slaves used to be
struck off to the highest
bidder - I was to have been
the guest of Mrs. E.A. [Wesminster?]
2716 - Delmar Ave - but
went with Mrs. Gross - to hotel -
Went to A.M. session
& remained at Hotel at
evening session with Mrs. Gross
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits St. Louis, stays at the Planter's Hotel, attends the Mississippi Valley Woman's Conference, and gives a speech in the evening.

entries.fullText:
In St. Louis
At the Planters -
Went to A.M. Session
Mississippi Valley Woman's
Conference - a W.C.T.U
& yet all suffrage talk -
& at close of sessions people
were asked to join W.C.T.U.
remained home in P.M. &
tried to take a sleep -
Made an hours speech
in evening to a large & paid
audience - All the rest had
been free admission --
Mrs Gross went with us --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the Mississippi Valley Woman's Conference, gives a paid speech in the evening, and rests in the afternoon.

entries.fullText:
In St. Louis -
This Missouri State Wom
Suffrage Association - held
morning & afternoon sessions -
- elected Mrs E.P. Johnson
President.
Miss Shaw
had to take 8.20 P.M.
train for Kansas City -
so was not at the
Banquet given at the
Mercantile Club rooms - in
honor of S.B.A. - Some
100 - at tables - Mrs
Ingalls managed and
presided beautifully
-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in St. Louis for the Missouri State Women's Suffrage Association meeting. Mrs E.P. Johnson was elected President. Miss Shaw had to leave early and did not attend the banquet in honor of Susan B. Anthony, which was managed and presided over by Mrs. Ingalls.

entries.fullText:
In St Louis -
Mrs Gross took me a
drive of four hours -
called on Mrs Meriwether
at her son Rivers -
& drove through the
Parks - a lovely
drive - & then
back to Planters
to dinner - she taking
the 8.55 - Alton train for
Chicago - & I the 8.20 -
Mo. Pacific train for
Leavenworth - Miss
Taylor & Mrs E. P. Johnson
wanted to see Mrs Gross off -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day in St. Louis, taking a four-hour drive with Mrs. Gross and visiting Mrs. Meriwether at her son Rivers. They drove through the parks and had dinner at Planters. Mrs. Gross left for Chicago and Susan B. Anthony left for Leavenworth, while Miss Taylor and Mrs. E. P. Johnson saw Mrs. Gross off.

entries.fullText:
Reached Leavenworth
at 9.25 - Found
brother D.R. at station
- spent the day guest
at the house -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived at Leavenworth and spent the day as a guest at her brother D.R.'s house.

entries.fullText:
Left Leavenworth
at 9.05 A.M - on Union
Pacific - at 11.20 - at
Topeka station - Mrs Lucia
O. Case & Dr. Harding met
me - and dear Miss Lyon
came in sight after
the train had started!!
Took sleeper at Topeka
wrote some letters then
dozed - & at 2 took
dinner - at 8 - went
to bed - The weather
hot - but a cool breeze
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Leavenworth and arrived at Topeka where she was met by Mrs Lucia O. Case and Dr. Harding. Miss Lyon arrived after the train had started. Susan took a sleeper and had dinner at 2 PM.

entries.fullText:
Reached Denver at
4 a.m. but remained
in sleeper until six
20 - Then took carriage
after some search -
found I was to be the
guest of Mrs. Thomas M
Patterson -
Pennsylvania Avenue -
Found a warm welcome
- Mrs P & her sister Mrs
Campbel wrote the Colorado
Chapter for W.S. [?isby]
They have only one daughter -
left - out of five children - &
she - Maude - is soon to
be married -
at 4.35 - took train for
Boulder - Where I was the
guest of Mrs. Jennette Bennett
Dunham - Had a small
audience - But on the whole
not bad - The Salvation
Army - with their after Geril Coxy - [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Denver and stayed with Mrs. Thomas M Patterson and Mrs. Campbel. She then took a train to Boulder and stayed with Mrs. Jennette Bennett Dunham. She had a small audience but not bad.

entries.fullText:
Left Boulder at 8.15 -
Was introduced to Judge &
Mrs. Jay H. Boughton - of
Fort Collins - & had a
nice chat with them -
Miss Maude met me - & we
called at Gov Routts & found
Rev. Anna there - She arrived
at 4 A.M -
A reception at the
Brown Palace Hotel
this P.M. from 3. to 5 - &
meeting this evening in the
Broadway Theater
A splendid audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Boulder and was introduced to Judge & Mrs. Jay H. Boughton of Fort Collins. She attended a reception at the Brown Palace Hotel and a meeting in the Broadway Theater where she had a splendid audience.

entries.fullText:
Left Denver at 2.25 - P.M.
for Cheyenne - Wyoming -
Train late - Guests of
Senator & Mrs. Joseph Carey -
Elegant dinner meeting - at
7.30 - & it was full half past
eight - if not 9 oclock when
we reached the new Baptist
Church - Gov Rich presided -
- Mrs Cary had to dinner Mrs Rich
Mrs Post - Mrs Warren & the
pioneer Esther Morris -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Denver to Cheyenne, Wyoming, and attends an elegant dinner meeting hosted by Senator and Mrs. Joseph Carey. They later attend a meeting at the new Baptist Church presided over by Gov Rich, where they dine with Mrs. Rich, Mrs. Post, Mrs. Warren, and pioneer Esther Morris.

entries.fullText:
Left Cheyenne at 7.20
- Soon learned that
Mrs Leland Stanfords [?]
car was attached to the
rear of the train - & near
noon she sent for me to
visit her - She was looking
well & told me of the
governments suit against
the estate - for $15,000,000 -
principal & interest - of loan to
the Central Pacific -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Cheyenne and learns that Mrs. Leland Stanford's car is attached to the rear of the train. She visits Mrs. Stanford, who tells her about the government's lawsuit against the estate for $15,000,000 in principal and interest of a loan to the Central Pacific.

entries.fullText:
Arrived Salt Lake, Utah
at 2 A.M. remained in
sleeper until 7. A.M. then
found E.B. Wells & 50 or 60 ladies
awaiting us. Drove to the
Templeton Hotel. Where
70 or more ladies took breakfast
with us. Then we drove
an hour about the city.
Miss Shaw stopping with Mrs.
McVickar and I with
Beatie, a daughter of Aunt
Zina Huntington and Brigham
Young. The mother there. Also
the husband's mother Beatie
with three children.
Miss Shaw preached in the great
Tabernacle. Filled. Bishop Whitney
followed with some Mormon doctrine.
that God was once a man & through
perfection grew into god!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Salt Lake, Utah and had breakfast with 70 or more ladies at the Templeton Hotel. She then drove around the city and attended a preaching at the Tabernacle where Bishop Whitney talked about Mormon doctrine.

entries.fullText:
In Salt lake.
Meeting in Constitutional
Hall - City Hall Building -
Crowded to suffocation - even
in A.M. - at evening it was
unbearable - so announced
that meeting tomorrow would
be in the Mormon
Assembly Hall - where
the Bishops hold their
meetings - & that was
packed at evening —
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a meeting in Constitutional Hall in Salt Lake, which was crowded to suffocation. The meeting was moved to the Mormon Assembly Hall the next day.

entries.fullText:
In Salt Lake
Assembly Hall
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Salt Lake at the Assembly Hall on May 14, 1895.

entries.fullText: Ogden
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Ogden on May 15, 1895.

entries.fullText:
Reached
Reno- Nevada
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reached Reno, Nevada on May 16, 1895.

entries.fullText: Reno Nevada
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Reno, Nevada on May 17, 1895.

entries.fullText:
The Pacific Slope
Women's Congress.
San Francisco
Mrs. George T. Gaden - Secy
entries.summaryText: Attended Women's Congress in San Francisco with Mrs. George T. Gaden as secretary.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Maria Freeman Gray
316. Montgomery Street
San Francisco - Cal -
entries.summaryText: Visited Mrs. Maria Freeman Gray at 316 Montgomery Street in San Francisco, California.

entries.fullText: [?] Miss Shaw preached for [?] [?] [?] [?] the closing & [?] sermon in the Jewish Synagogue [?] [?]
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw preached the closing sermon in the Jewish Synagogue.

entries.fullText: Attended the Congregationalist's [?] [?] at [?] [?] [?] - Women & of
entries.summaryText: Attended the Congregationalist's event for Women.

entries.fullText:
Left San Francisco
at 6 PM - after a
busy day packing
& seeing people -
for yosemite [velly?]
With Miss Shaw -
Dr Elizabeth &
nephew 16 Henry A. Baker
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left San Francisco with Miss Shaw, Dr Elizabeth, and nephew 16 Henry A. Baker for Yosemite after a busy day packing and seeing people.

entries.fullText:
Left o
after breakfast -
on stage -
lunched at - &
dined & slept at
Wawona -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left after breakfast on stage, lunched at an unknown location, and dined and slept at Wawona.

entries.fullText: Left Wawona Hotel at 7 o clock - and reached Yosemite Valley at 12.00 -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Wawona Hotel and arrived at Yosemite Valley.

entries.fullText: In Yosemite valley made the Vernal + Nevada falls trail -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony hiked the Vernal and Nevada falls trail in Yosemite Valley.

entries.fullText: visited Mirror Lake in the morning - and in the pm made the valley drive to the Cascades
entries.summaryText: Visited Yosemite falls, Mirror Lake in the morning and made the valley drive to the Cascades in the afternoon.

entries.fullText: The Yosemite valley
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about the Yosemite valley.

entries.fullText:
In Yosemite valley
made the glacier
Point trail
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony made the glacier Point trail in Yosemite valley.

entries.fullText:
Texas Annual Con at
Dallas - remember to write them
Yosemite- Cal.
Hay and self took nice
drive down the valley
to the cascades in
A.M. and then took
stage at 1.20 to go
out of the valley
Ridgeway (thru pines)
took a last glimpse
of the Wonders as
we drove up the
mountain for on the south
West - via Inspiration Point
Spent the night at the
Wawona Hotel.
Mrs Harland Mrs
Fisher & Miss Crane came
out of the valley with us
while Dr. Taryout & Shaw
made the Yosemite Falls trail
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended the Texas Annual Conference in Dallas and then traveled to Yosemite, where she took a drive down the valley and spent the night at the Wawona Hotel. She was accompanied by Mrs. Harland, Mrs. Fisher, and Miss Crane, while Dr. Taryout and Shaw made the Yosemite Falls trail.

entries.fullText:
Reached San Francisco
at 11:20
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in San Francisco.

entries.fullText:
Left San Francisco
3:30 for San Jose-
Mrs. Cooper & Hattie
called at Mrs. Sargents
Miss Shaw & Dr Lizzie
arrived from Josemite
at 11.20 - all O.K.
Mrs. Blinn & Mrs Harland
stayed to Luncheon
Nephew Hary A. Baker
called - & we had a
fun talk of himself & his
future - he decided
to go to San Diego - & into
the Sister's Hospital - a give
up the Lumber Camp
proposal - & thenceforth to
keep himself within the
limits of civilization - his
ship surgeon life for
four years - has told on him
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left San Francisco for San Jose and had visitors. Her nephew, Hary A. Baker, visited and decided to go to San Diego and give up the Lumber Camp proposal.

entries.fullText: guests of Mrs Sarah Knox Goodrich - Miss Shaw Preached at Santa Clara M.E. Church in A.M - at San Jose M.E. Church at 2.20 P.M-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and guests attended church services in Santa Clara and San Jose.
Susan B. Anthony did not write an entry on this day.

entries.fullText:
Leave San Jose - Cal
for Los Angeles
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves San Jose, California for Los Angeles on June 11, 1895.

entries.fullText: Los Angeles - Cal -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Los Angeles, California on June 12, 1895.

entries.fullText: Pomona Cal
Miss Shaw to preach.
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw to preach.

entries.fullText:
Wea. MON. JUNE 17, 1895 Ther.
San Diego.
entries.summaryText: Journal entry from June 17, 1895, written in San Diego.

entries.fullText: Wea. TUES. JUNE 17, 1895 Ther.
entries.summaryText: Journal entry from June 17, 1895.

entries.fullText: Ther.
entries.summaryText: Journal entry on June 21, 1895
Journal entry on June 22, 1895 from Los Angeles

entries.fullText:
Left Los angeles - at
2 P.M - a suffrage
Com. meeting on Mrs C.M.
Severances Piazza - and
Mrs Annie C. Severance
wife of Mark Sibley Severance
gave me $100- check to
make her a patron of the
National Council of Women -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Los Angeles after attending a suffrage committee meeting and receiving a $100 check from Mrs. Annie C. Severance to make her a patron of the National Council of Women.

entries.fullText:
Reach San Francisco -
at 10.45 A.M -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in San Francisco at 10:45 AM.

entries.fullText:
Farewell meeting in 1st
Congregational Church —
entries.summaryText: Farewell meeting in 1st Congregational Church.

entries.fullText: Lecture for Cal. W. S. Amendment campaign Committee - Sarah B. Cooper Pres - Metropolitan Temple - A splendid audience - - with a 50 cts - admission - our Farewell to San. Fran -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a lecture in San Francisco for the Cal. W. S. Amendment campaign Committee, with Sarah B. Cooper as President of the Metropolitan Temple. There was a splendid audience with a 50 cent admission fee. It was their farewell to San Francisco.

entries.fullText: At Mrs Sargents - Luncheon at Mrs Nellie Holbrook Blinn -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had lunch at Mrs. Nellie Holbrook Blinn's house after being at Mrs. Sargent's.

entries.fullText:
In San Francisco
This is my sister Guelma's
77th birth day - she was
born July 1. 1818 - & mother
& father were married July 13. 1817 -
Speak before the ministers
of all San. Fran. churches -
today at 1.20 - in Y.M.C.A Hall
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in San Francisco and celebrates her sister Guelma's 77th birthday. She also mentions her parents' wedding anniversary and a speaking engagement at the Y.M.C.A Hall.

entries.fullText:
California State W.S.A. Annual
Convention - which adopted
an new constitution &
elected Mrs A.A.
Sargent President
entries.summaryText: Annual convention held in California State where a new constitution was adopted and Mrs A.A. Sargent was elected President.

entries.fullText:
Celebration -
Miss Shaw spoke
in Woodward gardens
Hall to 4 or 5 000
[?ec??ell] - finished
to get to Oakland
where 1000's were
waiting to hear her
entries.summaryText: Celebration held in San Francisco where Miss Shaw spoke to a large audience at Woodward gardens Hall and then traveled to Oakland to speak to another large audience.

entries.fullText:
Joint Campaign Con
found at Mrs Sargents
this A.M.
Took train for home
at 6.30 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony found a Joint Campaign Con at Mrs Sargents and took a train home.

entries.fullText:
Found [?] - &
Mrs O[??] & friends met
us for a [?] at station
Mrs Shaw awoke
with fearful head
ache -- I made
pencil scribblings of my
trip
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony met with Mrs O[??] and friends at the station and Mrs Shaw had a headache. Susan made pencil scribblings of her trip.

entries.fullText:
This night Mrs Shaw
took Chicago sleeper &
I the Denver sleeper
& to Sara Good bye.
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Shaw and Susan B. Anthony take different sleepers to Chicago and Denver respectively, and say goodbye to Sara.

entries.fullText:
Reached Denver - & saw
a home friend & left 1 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reaches Denver, meets a friend and leaves at 1 P.M.

entries.fullText:
at Topeka - this
A.M.- Mrs. Ca[rr??] - Mrs
Lyon & Dr Hardy - [???]
went to Mrs Lyons
to dinner - & while
at station they said
we hold our city club
meeting tomorrow - what
shall we say & do
& to [????thleen] resolution
Reached Leavenworth at
[?] or 6pm
entries.summaryText: Attended a city club meeting in Topeka and discussed what to say and do, and a resolution with Mrs. Ca[rr??], Mrs. Lyon, Dr. Hardy, and [????thleen]. Reached Leavenworth at [?] or 6pm.

entries.fullText: at Leavenworth
entries.summaryText: At Leavenworth.

entries.fullText: These days
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a brief entry about 'these days'.

entries.fullText: [lasted?] Fort Scott -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a brief entry about being in Fort Scott.

entries.fullText: Fort Scott
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a brief entry stating she was in Fort Scott.

entries.fullText: Took cars for Chicago
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a brief entry stating she took a train to Chicago.

entries.fullText:
Spent this night in
Chicago
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the night in Chicago.

entries.fullText:
Took 10. A.M. train
with Mr. & Mrs. I. E. Gross
& Harriet Hashner- they
for Bar Harbor Maine - I
for home - its was
the hottest & most
uncomfortable day
I spent on the cars
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took a train with Mr. & Mrs. I. E. Gross and Harriet Hashner. They were going to Bar Harbor Maine while she was going home. It was a very hot and uncomfortable day on the train.

entries.fullText:
Arrived Rochester
at - O. A. M - got
carriage for home &
sat on door steps
& read the morning news
paper until it was
time for Sister Mary
to be astir -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Rochester and spent time reading the morning newspaper until Sister Mary woke up.

entries.fullText:
At home
& hot weather
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home and it was hot weather.

entries.fullText: Learned that Miss Shaw had grown worse & worse each day - & was very very ill with typhoid fever at the Cape Cod home - so I telegraphed I would fill her engagement at Lake Side the 26th
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw is very ill with typhoid fever at the Cape Cod home, so I will fill her engagement at Lake Side on the 26th.

entries.fullText: Left on night train for Lake Side Ohio
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left on a night train for Lake Side Ohio.

entries.fullText:
Ther.
reached Sandusky
Ohio - breakfasted
there -took [steam?]
& reached Lake Side
before noon
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reached Sandusky Ohio and Lake Side on July 25, 1895.

entries.fullText:
Ther.
Lakeside - Ohio
to fill appointment of
Rev. Anna Shaw - who
is ill at her Cape Cod
Cottage - spoke in
great auditorium at
11 A. M. - & when speech
was 2/0 done- all turned
black - still I managed
to make a closing [sendout?]
& sully back to my seat -
- the next I knew there
was a crowd around
me - blanched & speechless
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at Lakeside, Ohio on July 26, 1895, filling in for Rev. Anna Shaw who was ill at her Cape Cod Cottage. During her speech, she experienced a blackout but managed to make a closing statement before feeling unwell.

entries.fullText:
Took evening train - &
at Ashtabula -- Met
Mrs Upton -- who
come home with me --
entries.summaryText: Met Mrs Upton in Ashtabula and traveled home with me.

entries.fullText:
At home
Rachel - & Mrs Catt
with Mrs Upton & myself -
talked business affairs -
I feeling awfully stupid -
entries.summaryText: Had a business meeting with Rachel, Mrs Catt, and Mrs Upton at home and felt stupid.

entries.fullText:
[Silver Lake Com meeting
due - 2 P.M. to speak for Mrs
Ella Hawley Grossett - Warsaw]
entries.summaryText: Attended a Silver Lake Committee meeting to speak for Mrs. Ella Hawley Grossett in Warsaw.

entries.fullText: [nothing to transcribe]

Woman's Day -
to be this Saturday --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Woman's Day happening on Saturday at Silver Lake.

entries.fullText: [nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]
Wea. Fri. Aug. 16, 1895 Ther.
entries.summaryText: Journal entry dated August 16, 1895.

entries.fullText: Wea. Sat. Aug. 17, 1895 Ther. Sister Anna O. 51. to day
entries.summaryText: Journal entry dated August 17, 1895 mentioning Sister Anna O. turning 51 years old.

entries.fullText: [nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]
Woman's - Day - Mrs. Chapman Catt - & Rev Ida C. Hultin speakers - Sister Mary there -
entries.summaryText: Attended Woman's Day event in Lily Dale with speeches from Mrs. Chapman Catt and Rev Ida C. Hultin, and Sister Mary was also present.

entries.fullText:
At home - & on the [gai?]
Brother D.R. 71. to day & his
son D.R. Jr. - 25 to day -
Mrs. C.C. came home
from Lily Dale with Sister
Mary - arriving at 3:22.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Brother D.R., D.R. Jr., Mrs. C.C., and Sister Mary visiting her at home.

entries.fullText:
On the [gai?]
Mrs. C. C. here - talking
on her organization work
& bulletin
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Mrs. C. C. visiting her and discussing organization work and a bulletin.

entries.fullText: [nothing to transcribe]
entries.summaryText: No entry written on August 24th, 1895

entries.fullText:
still writing -
Mrs Emma B. Sweet
come - I worked all
day for Mrs. C.C. - writing
letters & making copies
of matter for bulletin -
Mrs. C.C. took the
train at 9:45 for
Cleveland - & other
Ohio points en route
for Helena to Montana
State U.S. Convention -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about working on letters and copies for a bulletin for Mrs. C.C. and Mrs. C.C. leaving for Cleveland and other Ohio points en route to Helena for the Montana State U.S. Convention. Emma B. Sweet also visited.

entries.fullText: [nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]

Mrs C.C. to speak at
Lake Brady Camp -
in Ohio -
entries.summaryText: Mrs C.C. is scheduled to speak at Lake Brady Camp in Ohio.

entries.fullText:
Went R. R. station
Lake Brady Camp - Ohio -
Mrs [Augustis?] [Armsbig?]
195 - 14th st - Buffalo NY
-- Couldn't go - & so wrote
Mrs A. weeks ago -
My nurse - Mrs Magdalene
Kelly McCutcheon - of
Calcury - Canada - left
for her home this evening -
After a three weeks & four
days of most faithful work
in caring for me —

Sister Annie & Niece
Maude did not come
to night - telegram said
They had decided to visit
Cousin Ellen again
in South Orange N - Jersey
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about various people and locations, including her nurse who left after three weeks of caring for her, and her sister and niece who decided to visit a cousin in South Orange N - Jersey instead of visiting her.

entries.fullText:
My first bath
and dressing alone
this a.m.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about taking her first bath and dressing alone.

entries.fullText:
Wea. SUN. SEPT. 1, 1895 Ther.

Lovely day- cool-
walked to cor. Spring & Fitzhugh
Streets - & called on Maria
Porter- Then May Hallowell's -
& then to West Avenue - & rode
home in street car -
Mrs L. C. Smith & daughter
Mrs [Lenner?] called -
Sister Anna O. & niece
Maude arrived from South
Orange on 9.25 train
this evening - nephew D R. Jr
remained in New York
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her day on September 1, 1895, which included visiting friends and family, walking around town, and receiving visitors.

entries.fullText:
Wea. MON. SEPT. 2, 1895 Ther

Sister Anna O. & niece
Maude went to Niagara Falls
this morning - nephew D R. Jr
returned to New York -
I remained at home all day
alone -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her family's travel plans and her day at home alone on September 2, 1895.

entries.fullText: [nothing to transcribe]
Nephew D.R. Jr arrived this A.M -
entries.summaryText: Nephew D.R. Jr arrived

entries.fullText: [nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]
Sister Annie Maud & self remained at home - Sister May went to church to hear Mr. Gannett - but said she heard only the first words of each sentence -
entries.summaryText: Sister Annie Maud and Susan B. Anthony stayed at home while Sister May went to church to hear Mr. Gannett, but had trouble hearing the full sentences.

entries.fullText:
Weather cool -
Sister Anna O. &
niece Maude left
for Leavenworth on
the 10.27 train this night
sister May went
to the train with them
entries.summaryText: Sister Anna O. & niece Maude left for Leavenworth on the 10.27 train this night, sister May went to the train with them.

entries.fullText: [nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]
[nothing to transcribe]

South Dakota's - annual Con
at Pierre - 16.&17- Mrs. C. C. to
be there - Anna R. Simmons - Pres -
entries.summaryText: Annual convention in Pierre, South Dakota with Mrs. C. C. and Anna R. Simmons in attendance.
